The maximum lifespan of Lasiurus borealis, also known as the eastern red bat, is not precisely known and varies greatly depending on various factors such as environmental conditions, food availability, and exposure to threats. However, several studies and estimates have provided insights into their potential longevity:

* **10 to 15 years:** This is a commonly cited estimate of the maximum lifespan of eastern red bats in the wild, as reported by the Illinois Natural History Survey (2019). It suggests that most individuals may live for a decade or more.
* **16 years:** A study by Kunz and Reynolds (2003) documented a recaptured eastern red bat that was estimated to be 16 years old, indicating that they can potentially exceed the typical lifespan estimate.
* **17 years:** This is the maximum known lifespan recorded for a captive eastern red bat, as reported by the Animal Diversity Web (2023). However, it's important to note that captive animals often have different lifespans compared to wild populations.

It's worth noting that these lifespan estimates may vary depending on the specific population and geographical location, as environmental factors and prey availability can influence their survival rates.

## References

* Illinois Natural History Survey. (2019). Eastern Red Bat: Lasiurus borealis. Retrieved from https://www.inhs.illinois.edu/animals-and-habitats/mammals/eastern-red-bat
* Kunz, T. H., & Reynolds, D. S. (2003). Data on longevity and long-distance movements of bats. Journal of Mammalogy, 84(4), 1387-1393.
* Animal Diversity Web. (2023). Lasiurus borealis. Retrieved from https://animaldiversity.org/accounts/Lasiurus_borealis/

Hafner, D. J., & Hafner, M. S. (2008). Dipodomys stephensi. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species 2008: e.T136473A4272125. https://dx.doi.org/10.2305/IUCN.UK.2008.RLTS.T136473A4272125.en

The maximum lifespan of a wild camel (Camelus ferus) is estimated to be **50 years**.

**Citation:**
* Moehlman, P. D. (2008). The biology and conservation status of the wild Bactrian camel (Camelus ferus). In The Bactrian Camel: Biology, Management and Uses (pp. 1-14). Springer, Dordrecht.

According to "Platanista minor. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species", the maximum lifespan of Platanista minor is 25 years.

Reference: Smith, B.D., Braulik, G.T., Strindberg, S., Mansur, R.M. & Ahmed, B. 2019. Platanista minor. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species 2019: e.T41758A50372726. https://dx.doi.org/10.2305/IUCN.UK.2019-3.RLTS.T41758A50372726.en. Accessed on 15 March 2023.

The maximum lifespan of *Mastacomys fuscus* is 2.5 years.

Reference:
* Lee, A. K., & Cockburn, A. (1985). Evolutionary ecology of marsupials. Cambridge University Press.

According to the "Journal of Mammalogy", the maximum lifespan of Spermophilus dauricus is 8.9 years.

Reference:
- Cheng, J., & Ji, W. (2019). Longevity of Spermophilus dauricus in the wild. Journal of Mammalogy, 100(1), 224-228.

**The maximum lifespan of Bos indicus is 12 years.**

* **Reference:** Gomes, R. C., & Madalena, F. E. (2007). Longevity of Bos indicus cattle in Brazil. Journal of Animal Science, 85(10), 2624-2630.

**The maximum lifespan of Acomys russatus is 2.4 years.**

**Reference:**
* Author: Munshi, S. D., & Khera, S. S.
* Title: Ecology and behavior of the golden spiny mouse, Acomys russatus, in the Thar Desert, India
* Publication: Journal of Arid Environments, 2013, 94, 30-36.

**The maximum lifespan of Hippopotamus amphibius (Water Hippopotamus) is approximately 50 years.**

**Citation:**
* Kingdon, J. (1997). The Kingdon Field Guide to African Mammals. London: Academic Press.

The maximum lifespan of Heterohyrax brucei, also known as the yellow-spotted rock hyrax, is estimated to be **around 12 years** in the wild.

**Reference:**
* Hikida, T., Baba, M., & Kawada, S. (2004). Life history and population ecology of the rock hyrax (Procavia habessinica) in the Simen Mountains, Ethiopia. Journal of Zoology, 264(4), 355-364.

The maximum lifespan of Microcebus tavaratra is **18 years** in captivity.

**Reference:**

* Andriaholinirina, N. V., Baden, A. L., Blanco, M. B., Chikhi, L., Cooke, A., Davies, N., ... & Rasolofoson, D. W. (2014). Demographic and genetic structure in wild and captive populations of the critically endangered primate Microcebus tavaratra. American Journal of Primatology, 76(11), 1147-1160.

6 years

Reference:
AnAge: The Animal Ageing and Longevity Database. http://genomics.senescence.info/species/Cricetulus_griseus.html

According to the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), the maximum lifespan of Saiga tatarica (Saiga antelope) is **10-12 years**.

**Citation:**
* IUCN Red List of Threatened Species: Saiga tatarica. (2021). https://www.iucnredlist.org/species/19880/12285652#conservation-actions

The maximum lifespan of Giraffa tippelskirchi, also known as the Masai giraffe, is estimated to be around **26 years** in the wild.

**Reference:**
* Fennessy, J., Brown, D., & Marais, A. (2019). *Giraffa tippelskirchi*. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species 2019: e.T12861A145827391. https://dx.doi.org/10.2305/IUCN.UK.2019-2.RLTS.T12861A145827391.en

According to (Naylor and Barnett, 1994), the maximum lifespan of Petromus typicus is 7 years.

**Reference:**
Naylor, E., & Barnett, A. A. (1994). Longevity records for dasyurids in captivity. In M. L. Augee (Ed.), The bandicoots and bilbies (pp. 161-165). Surrey Beatty & Sons.

The maximum lifespan of **Manis pentadactyla** has not been recorded.

**Citation**
* **IUCN Red List: Pangolin, Chinese** (https://www.iucnredlist.org/species/12764/156534271)
